learning_outcomes.description: Explain the requirement of different protection schemes for the proper operation of power system.
Recognise factors to be considered when designing a power system protection scheme.
Demonstrate the operation of various components used in power system protection.
Calculate protection settings when designing a protection scheme for a simple power system network and components.
Identify challenges and current developments in power system protection.

assessments.task_description:
Two assignments need to be completed during the applied class in Week 4 and Week 10. More information on assignment will be available in Blackboard. All submissions are collected during the class. Overall worth of these submissions will be 20 marks. The assignments are equally weighted. Note that this is not an identity verified or supervised assessment. Students have the freedom to discuss with peers in the class.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
This is mainly based on PSCAD simulation exercise. PSCAD training will be provided for 5 weeks starting week 3. More information about the simulation exercise will be available through Blackboard. A completed report based on the simulation exercise has to be submitted. More information related to structure of the report will be provided through Blackboard. A viva is conducted during the presentations to discuss about your understanding about the content covered in the report and report marks will be weighted based on the student performance during viva. More information related marking criteria will be available through Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures on various topics

Series of lectures covering fault analysis and various protection schemes used in the power systems. Some of the lectures will be covered by the industry experts. Following topics will be covered in this course : Fault analysis, symmetrical components, Relay operation, Different types of relays, Relay coordination, Unit protection, Instrument Transformers, IEC 61850 requirements, effect of renewables on protection schemes

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
